Capt. Clarkset out on a hunting party with 18 men
visited by many of the savages today.—
February
8th

visited by the black Catwho dined with me the Black &
white & Speckled woodpecker has returned—
visited by Mr. McKinsey, very little snow

Mr. Mckinseyleaves me
Charbonoreturns with out
horses or meat
Capt. Clarkand party returned from hunting
14th
The Snow fell 3 Inches deep last night

LewisSet out in pursute of a party of Souiswho forced 2
horses from a party (Dispatched after meat on the river
below) with 24 men

the Indians who went with Capt Lewisreturned last
night— Visited by Mr. McKinsey
Mr. McKinseyliave me
Cap Lewisreturn with about 3, 1〈00〉 w of meat
got the poplar perogue out of the ice.
loosed the boat & large perogue from the ice.

Visited by the principall Chiefs of the Mar-har-ha& the
Min-ne-tar-re—Matehartar.— also Mr. Bunch, engage
of the H B Copy
got the Boat and perogus on the bank
27th
got the Boat and Perogues on the bank.
Mr. Gravlinarrived with some Ricaras& two frenchmen

div.note: This weather table follows Lewis'sin his Weather Diary, with discrepancies between it and Clark'stable in Codex C being noted. Clarkwrote the remarks in the Weather Diary for Februrary 15–21 and probably also the table for those dates.

Lewisreversed the "Weather" and "Wind at 4 oCk. P. M." columns, as he had done with the latter part of January 1805 on the same pages, through February 24. The error is corrected here to avoid confusion.
This temperature is "29 a" in Clark'sCodex C table.
Lewishas no indication of rise or fall, but gives the figure "½"; Clarkgives neither rise nor fall nor a figure.
Clark'swind direction here is either blank or illegible.
The remarks here follow Lewis'sWeather Diary; Clarkevidently wrote those for February 15, 17, 18, and 21. In Codex C Clarkwrote remarks only for the eighth and fourteenth; his dates are used there.
The yellow-bellied sapsucker, Sphyrapicus varius[AOU, 402], has been suggested, Holmgren, 33.

Perhaps the only evidence of what sort of wood either pirogue was made of; from the remark of the next day this would be the smaller, or white, pirogue. See Saindon (WP). Since it is unclear when the captains obtained the white pirogue, it can not be determined what sort of "poplar" is meant. It may have been a variety of Populus, but could have been constructed in the East from a variety of Liriodendron, tulip-poplar. Maximilian called attention to the use of the tulip-poplar for carpentry work in Ohio in 1833 and noted that it was locally known as "poplar." Maximilian Journal, January 4, 1833, The InterNorth Art Foundation Collection, Center for Western Studies, Joslyn Art Museum, Omaha. See also September 4, 1803. Moulton (NWP). On March 27 (given as March 28) Clarkmentions cottonwood in connection with the pirogues, but it is unclear whether he means the construction of the vessels or the additions being made to them. In fact, he may have been referring only to the newly constructed canoes.
